title: Joe Biden
added: {{See also|List of things named after Joe Biden}}

title: Joe Biden
deleted: In retrospect, Biden's family came to believe the early end to his presidential campaign had been a blessing in disguise, for had he still been campaigning in 1988, he might well not have stopped to seek medical attention and the condition might have become unsurvivable.<ref>Biden, ''Promises to Keep'', p. 225</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/05/04/us/biden-resting-after-surgery-for-second-brain-aneurysm.html|title=Biden Resting After Surgery For Second Brain Aneurysm|date=May 4, 1988|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> In 2013, Biden said, "they take a saw and they cut your head off", and "they literally had to take the top of my head off." He also said he was told he would have less than a 50% chance of full recovery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/campaigns/surgeon-who-operated-on-joe-biden-hes-better-now-than-before-brain-surgery|title=Surgeon who operated on Biden: He's better now than before brain surgery|date=April 26, 2019|website=Washington Examiner}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: He told her he aimed to become a senator by the age of 30 and then president.<ref name="dmn-87">{{cite news|last=Leubsdorf|first=Carl P.|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_text_direct-0=0ED3CF5858543A33&p_field_direct-0=document_id|title=Biden Keeps Sights Set On White House|date=September 6, 1987|newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]]}} Reprinted in {{cite news|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/washington/cleubsdorf/stories/082308dnpolbiden87profile.4d6e19b.html|title=Lifelong ambition led Joe Biden to Senate, White House aspirations|date=August 23, 2008|newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080919060037/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/washington/cleubsdorf/stories/082308dnpolbiden87profile.4d6e19b.html|archivedate=September 19, 2008}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: The incident resurfaced in 1987 during [[Joe Biden 1988 presidential campaign|his first run for president]].<ref name=wpbclina/><ref name=ctbadmerr/><ref name="nyt091887">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/us/biden-admits-plagiarism-in-school-but-says-it-was-not-malevolent.html |title=Biden Admits Plagiarism in School But Says It Was Not 'Malevolent' |last=Dionne |first==E. J., Jr. |newspaper=The New York Times |date=September 18, 1987 |authorlink= E. J. Dionne}}</ref><ref name="Slate">{{cite news |last=Greenberg |first=David |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2008/08/why-biden-s-plagiarims-shouldn-t-be-forgotten.html |title=The Write Stuff? Why Biden's plagiarism shouldn't be forgotten |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=August 25, 2008 |accessdate=December 30, 2019 }}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: On May 30, 2015, Biden's son [[Beau Biden]] died at age 46 after having battled [[Glioblastoma|brain cancer]] for several years. The nature and seriousness of the illness had not been previously disclosed to the public, and Biden had quietly reduced his public schedule to spend more time with Beau.<ref name=allabout>{{cite news|title=Delaware's 2016 speculation all about Biden |first=Jonathan |last=Starkey |url=https://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/local/2014/11/08/delawares-speculation-biden/18727837/ |accessdate=November 9, 2014 |newspaper=Delaware Online |date=November 8, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Governor>{{cite news |url=https://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/local/2015/01/25/beau-biden-governor/22326393/ |title=Beau Biden for governor?|newspaper=Delaware Online |date=January 26, 2015 |accessdate=January 27, 2015 |first=Jonathan |last=Starkey }}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: In an unusual move, Biden shared campaign planes with one of his rivals for the nomination, Senator [[Chris Dodd]] of [[Connecticut]]. Dodd and Biden were friends and seeking to save funds during somewhat long-shot efforts at the nomination.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/16/us/politics/biden-obama-history.html|title=Obama and Biden's Relationship Looks Rosy. It Wasn't Always That Simple.|last=Thrush|first=Glenn|date=August 16, 2019|work=The New York Times|access-date=October 30, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: Biden never [[List of tie-breaking votes cast by vice presidents of the United States|cast a tie-breaking vote in the Senate]], making him the longest-serving vice president with this distinction.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/pence-has-already-done-something-biden-never-did-break-a-senate-tie/|title=Pence Has Already Done Something Biden Never Did: Break A Senate Tie|last=Bycoffe|first=Aaron|date=February 7, 2017|website=[[FiveThirtyEight]]|quote=Twelve vice presidents, including Biden, never broke a tie; Biden was the longest-serving vice president to never do so.}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: On July 15, 2019, the nonprofit Biden Cancer Initiative announced it would cease operations for the foreseeable future. Biden and his wife left the initiative's board in April as an ethics precaution before starting his presidential campaign.<ref>{{cite news |last=Braun |first=Stephen |url=https://www.apnews.com/97adeafe979943808a3abe963e089135 |title=Biden cancer nonprofit suspends operations indefinitely |work=[[Associated Press]] |date=July 15, 2019 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20190715151134/https://www.apnews.com/97adeafe979943808a3abe963e089135 |archivedate=July 15, 2019 |accessdate=July 16, 2019 }}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: During Biden's first year at Syracuse he failed a course after submitting a paper that relied almost exclusively on a ''[[Fordham Law Review]]'' article, which he had cited only once, and drew "chunks of heavy legal prose directly" from it;<ref name="nyt091887"/> Biden said he had not understood the proper rules of citation.<ref name="nyt091887">{{cite news | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE3DB143FF93BA2575AC0A961948260 | title= Biden Admits Plagiarism in School But Says It Was Not 'Malevolent' | last=Dionne | first=E. J., Jr. | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=September 18, 1987 | authorlink= E. J. Dionne}}</ref> He repeated the course and passed with high marks.<ref>{{cite news | author=Lee May | title=Biden Admits Plagiarism in Writing Law School Brief | newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=September 18, 1987 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/print/1987-09-18/news/mn-5748_1_law-school}}</ref> In 1987, the Delaware Supreme Court's Board of Professional Responsibility reviewed the incident at Biden's request, and concluded that he had violated no rules.<ref name="nyt-cleared">{{cite news | title=Professional Board Clears Biden In Two Allegations of Plagiarism | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DE1DD1230F93AA15756C0A96F948260 | agency=[[Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=May 29, 1989}}</ref> Biden graduated with a [[Juris Doctor|law degree]] in 1968, ranked 76th in his class of 85,<ref name=wpbclina/><ref name=ctbadmerr/> and was [[Admission to the bar in the United States|admitted]] to the [[Delaware State Bar Association|Delaware bar]] in 1969.<ref name="cong-bio">{{cite dictionary |dictionary=[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=B000444 |title=Biden, Joseph Robinette, Jr.|accessdate=August 19, 2008}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
added: Biden graduated with a [[Juris Doctor|law degree]] in 1968, ranked 76th in his class of 85,<ref name=wpbclina/><ref name=ctbadmerr/> and was [[Admission to the bar in the United States|admitted]] to the [[Delaware State Bar Association|Delaware bar]] in 1969.<ref name="cong-bio">{{cite dictionary |dictionary=[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=B000444 |title=Biden, Joseph Robinette, Jr.|accessdate=August 19, 2008}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: Biden's "Kids 2000" legislation established a public-private partnership to provide computer centers, teachers, Internet access, and technical training to young people, particularly low-income and at-risk youth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biden.senate.gov/newsroom/details.cfm?id=229820&&|title=Kids 2000 Program|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223064751/http://biden.senate.gov/newsroom/details.cfm?id=229820&& |archivedate=December 23, 2007|accessdate=August 23, 2008}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
added: In October, 780 retired generals, admirals, senior noncommissioned officers, ambassadors and senior national security officials signed a letter endorsing Biden.<ref>https://www.nationalsecurityleaders4biden.com/</ref>

title: Joe Biden
added: In October, 780 retired generals, admirals, senior noncommissioned officers, ambassadors and senior national security officials signed a letter endorsing Biden.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nationalsecurityleaders4biden.com/|publisher=National Security Leaders for Biden |accessdate=October 22, 2020| title=An Open Letter to America}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
added: In 2006, Delaware newspaper columnist Harry F. Themal wrote that Biden "occupies the sensible center of the Democratic Party".<ref name="themal">{{cite news | title=Biden says he's on track for 2008 run | author=Themal, Harry F. | work=[[The News Journal]] | date=January 23, 2006}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: Biden made controversial remarks during the campaign.  Biden had also been criticized in July 2006 for a remark he made about his support among [[Indian Americans]]: "I've had a great relationship. In Delaware, the largest growth in population is Indian-Americans moving from India. You cannot go to a 7-Eleven or a Dunkin' Donuts unless you have a slight Indian accent. I'm not joking."<ref name="cbs070706">{{cite news |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/bidens-comments-ruffle-feathers/ |title=Biden's Comments Ruffle Feathers, Senator Forced To Explain His Remarks About Indian-Americans |date=July 7, 2006 |accessdate=August 24, 2008 |publisher=[[CBS News]]}}</ref> Biden later said the remark was not intended to be derogatory.<ref name="cbs070706" />{{refn|group=nb|The Indian-American activist who was on the receiving end of Biden's comment said he was "100 percent behind [Biden] because he did nothing wrong."<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Distaso |title=Indian-American activist defends Sen. Biden |url=http://www.unionleader.com/article.aspx?headline=Indian-American+activist+defends+Sen.+Biden&articleId=0108a2f4-0530-4860-b010-5b076007bff6 | newspaper = [[New Hampshire Union Leader]] | date = July 10, 2006 | accessdate = February 1, 2008 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070228073804/http://www.unionleader.com/article.aspx?headline=Indian-American+activist+defends+Sen.+Biden&articleId=0108a2f4-0530-4860-b010-5b076007bff6 |archive-date=February 28, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref>}}
